image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: RBA governor Philip Lowe is speaking in Brisbane where he's expected to discuss changes to the bank's structure and reasons for pausing its current rate hiking cycle last week. Follow live.

title.children: RBA governor set to discuss changes to bank's structure and reasons for rate pause, ASX higher on commodity prices

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 is up 0.4 per cent to 7,135 after a strong start to trade today. Some sectors have slipped in today's trade with healthcare, tech stocks and utilities among the sectors weighing on the market. Energy stocks and miners are driving the gains after rises in commodity prices overnight. Data centre operator Megaport (+4.6 per cent) is doing the best, while Bellevue Gold (-5.7 per cent) is doing the worst.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX 200 comes off highs at lunchtime

children.content: The ASX 200 is up 0.4 per cent to 7,135 after a strong start to trade today.
Some sectors have slipped in today's trade with healthcare, tech stocks and utilities among the sectors weighing on the market.
Energy stocks and miners are driving the gains after rises in commodity prices overnight.
Data centre operator Megaport (+4.6 per cent) is doing the best, while Bellevue Gold (-5.7 per cent) is doing the worst.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has kept its official cash rate steady at 5.5 per cent at its meeting today. The RBNZ said official rates are constraining spending and inflation pressure as anticipated and required. "The committee agreed that the OCR (official cash rate) will need to remain at a restrictive level for the foreseeable future, to ensure that consumer price inflation returns to the 1 to 3 per cent annual target range, while supporting maximum sustainable employment." "In New Zealand, inflation is expected to continue to decline from its peak, and with it measures of inflation expectations." "Core inflation is expected to decline as capacity constraints ease. " "While employment is above its maximum sustainable level, there are signs of labour market pressures dissipating and vacancies declining." The bank says increased migration is seeing labour shortages start to ease, and house prices are now at around sustainable levels. New Zealand home prices boomed by nearly 50 per cent during the pandemic, but have since fallen by 17 per cent from their peak in December 2021. Annual inflation in New Zealand is running at 6.7 per cent and the economy is in recession.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Zealand keeps interest rates on hold

children.content: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has kept its official cash rate steady at 5.5 per cent at its meeting today.
The RBNZ said official rates are constraining spending and inflation pressure as anticipated and required.

"The committee agreed that the OCR (official cash rate) will need to remain at a restrictive level for the foreseeable future, to ensure that consumer price inflation returns to the 1 to 3 per cent annual target range, while supporting maximum sustainable employment."
"In New Zealand, inflation is expected to continue to decline from its peak, and with it measures of inflation expectations."
"Core inflation is expected to decline as capacity constraints ease. "
"While employment is above its maximum sustainable level, there are signs of labour market pressures dissipating and vacancies declining."
The bank says increased migration is seeing labour shortages start to ease, and house prices are now at around sustainable levels.
New Zealand home prices boomed by nearly 50 per cent during the pandemic, but have since fallen by 17 per cent from their peak in December 2021.
Annual inflation in New Zealand is running at 6.7 per cent and the economy is in recession.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Federal Government says its disappointed that China has asked for another month to complete a review needed to lift tariffs on barley. It's warned it would resume a case at the World Trade Organisation if there is a further delay. Australia agreed to temporarily suspend the case in April after Beijing agreed to finish the review in three months, with a possible fourth if required. "China has now requested this one-month extension, which we have agreed to," a spokesman for Foreign Minister Penny Wong and Trade Minister Don Farrell said. "While we are disappointed China's review could not be completed within the initial three months, we remain hopeful the impediments will be lifted in the near future." Diplomatic tensions between China and Australia have eased since the Labor Government came to power last year. In 2020, China imposed tariffs of 80.5 per cent on Australian barley imports for up to five years as part of a trade row. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China barley tariffs review delayed

children.content: The Federal Government says its disappointed that China has asked for another month to complete a review needed to lift tariffs on barley.
It's warned it would resume a case at the World Trade Organisation if there is a further delay.
Australia agreed to temporarily suspend the case in April after Beijing agreed to finish the review in three months, with a possible fourth if required.
"China has now requested this one-month extension, which we have agreed to," a spokesman for Foreign Minister Penny Wong and Trade Minister Don Farrell said.
"While we are disappointed China's review could not be completed within the initial three months, we remain hopeful the impediments will be lifted in the near future."
Diplomatic tensions between China and Australia have eased since the Labor Government came to power last year.
In 2020, China imposed tariffs of 80.5 per cent on Australian barley imports for up to five years as part of a trade row.
Reuters
